text.0: An anti–#SARSCoV2 antibody cocktail was given to patients within 3 days after PCR confirmation of #COVID19. In patients who were antibody-negative, treatment was associated with rapid viral clearance. The effect was less marked among patients who were antibody-positive.
text.1: In a randomized trial, the risk of mechanical ventilation or death among patients hospitalized with #COVID19 pneumonia was 12.0% in the tocilizumab group and 19.3% in the placebo group. Tocilizumab did not increase survival. #IDTwitter
text.2: The NEJM Race and Medicine topic page features a selection of NEJM articles on race and medicine with implications for improving patient care, professional training, research, and public health. All articles assembled on the page are freely available.
text.3: Our discussion "Negotiating Your First Contract," closes tomorrow, December 18. #MedStudentTwitter #MedTwitter
text.4: Among U.S. adults aged 25 to 44, there were 19% more deaths than expected — or 12,000 people — from March through July 2020. #COVID19
text.5: What’s the most appropriate additional test for an asymptomatic 65yo white man who has mild elevations in serum aminotransferases, lipids, and fasting glucose; a normal level of alkaline phosphatase; no history of alcohol use disorder… #MedEd https://t.co/6sPQPWP5mH https://t.co/9ouqFSm6Eq
text.6: Sex designations on birth certificates offer no clinical utility, and they can be harmful for intersex and transgender people. Moving such designations below the line of demarcation would not compromise the birth certificate’s public health function but could avoid harm.
text.7: https://t.co/4NNEmdSsxY is temporarily down. Our web administrators are actively working on the issue. Thank you for your patience.
text.8: In this audio interview conducted on December 16, 2020, the editors discuss the five types of Covid-19 vaccine under study, as well as trial results of the therapeutic agent baricitinib.
text.9: As a legacy of African enslavement, structural racism affects both population and individual health in three interrelated domains: redlining and racialized residential segregation, mass incarceration and police violence, and unequal medical care.
text.10: In a trial that compared a 2-week course of dexamethasone with placebo in patients with a chronic subdural hematoma, a favorable outcome on the modified Rankin scale at 6 months was more common in the placebo group than in the dexamethasone group.
text.11: In Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn v. Cuomo, the Supreme Court temporarily enjoined New York’s limits on in-person religious worship. The decision could have important implications for public health law during the #COVID19 pandemic and into the future.
text.12: Early in the spread of #SARSCoV2, the virus mutated into what is now the most prevalent genotype globally. The vaccines currently in clinical trials are based on the “ancestral” form of the virus. Recent studies provide clues about their effectiveness against the mutant form.
text.13: When a virtual White Coats for Black Lives “march” was disrupted by racist intruders, the organizers persevered. The diverse perspectives and collective support that allowed them to move forward are the tools needed for the long game of antiracism.
text.14: As a legacy of African enslavement, structural racism affects both population and individual health in three interrelated domains: redlining and racialized residential segregation, mass incarceration and police violence, and unequal medical care.
